questions.question: Which file contains all the drawing document-specific information, such as specifications for units, drafting standard, font selections, etc?
You need to design a steel spring with a pitch diameter of 3 inches, free length of 10 inches, and pitch of 1 inch. How would you accomplish this in SOLIDWORKS?
questions.answer: Create a new sketch of a circle with a diameter of 3 inches. Then use the Helix/Spiral curve command to define a height of 10 inches and pitch of 1 inch.
correctAnswer: Create a new sketch of a circle with a diameter of 3 inches. Then use the Helix/Spiral curve command to define a height of 10 inches and pitch of 1 inch.
options: Create a new sketch of a circle with a diameter of 1 inch. Then use the Helix/Spiral curve command and define a height of 10 inches and pitch of 3 inches.
Create a new sketch of a circle with a diameter of 3 inches. Then use the Helix/Spiral curve command to define a height of 10 inches and pitch of 1 inch.
First, create a new sketch of a circle of 10 inches. Then use the Helix/Spiral curve command and define by pitch of 1 inch and 3 revolutions.
Use the Helix/Spiral curve command and define a diameter of 3 inches, height of 10 inches, and pitch of 1 inch.

questions.answer: Add a concentric relation between the circles

options: Add a tangent relation between the circles

You want to focus on a single component within your assembly and hide all the rest. How can you do this?

questions.question: What will Save As do on an existing saved part?
questions.answer: It will keep the original part and save the current path with a new name
correctAnswer: It will keep the original part and save the current path with a new name
options: It will delete the original part and save the current part with a new name
It will keep the original part and save the current path with a new name
It will save both the original part and the new part in the current state
It will rename the original part

questions.question: You want to show a list of the raw materials, subassemblies, intermediate assemblies, subcomponents, and parts, and the quantities of each, needed to manufacture an end product. What would be useful to accomplish this?
Freezing a portion of a model can be used if you work with complex models with many features. Why
questions.answer: Freezing the features helps to reduce the rebuild time and prevent unintentional changes to the model
correctAnswer: Freezing the features helps to reduce the rebuild time and prevent unintentional changes to the model
options: Freezing the features helps to show only the critical features of the model
Freezing the features helps to show the internal features of the model
Freezing the features helps to reduce the rebuild time and prevent unintentional changes to the model
Freezing the features helps to show the external features of the model

questions.answer: Extruded Boss/Base, Revolved Boss/Base, and Sweep
correctAnswer: Extruded Boss/Base, Revolved Boss/Base, and Sweep
options: Shell, Revolved Boss/Base, and Extruded Boss/Base
Extruded Boss/Base, Revolved Boss/Base, and Sweep

questions.question: Which choice is NOT a standard mate within SOLIDWORKS?
How would you temporarily remove a feature from a model?
questions.answer: Click the feature in the FeatureManager design tree or graphics area, then select Suppress
correctAnswer: Click the feature in the FeatureManager design tree or graphics area, then select Suppress
options: Click the feature in the FeatureManager design tree or graphics area, then select Suppress
Drag the feature to the Suppression folder, located at the top of the FeatureManager design tree
You cannot remove features temporarily-you can only delete them completely
Drag the feature to the bottom of the FeatureManager design tree, then drag the Suppression bar above it

questions.question: You want to show an assembly's components spread out and positioned to show how they fit together when assembled. How do you accomplish this?
How would you fix a Lofted Boss/Base feature that appears twisted?
questions.answer: Drag the loft connectors to the correct position, or use guide curves
correctAnswer: Drag the loft connectors to the correct position, or use guide curves
options: Drag the loft connectors to the correct position, or use guide curves
Reduce the spacing between the loft profiles, then scale the loft body as required
Loft shapes are driven entirely by the loft profiles, adjust the skecthes to remove any ambiguity in the loft path
Ensure that the Twist Along Path option is not selected

questions.question: When creating a sweep feature, you receive this error: "Cannot get to a point on the path to start with. For an open path, the path must intersect with the section plane." How can you fix this?
questions.answer: Ensure that the path sketch touches the profile sketch at some point
correctAnswer: Ensure that the path sketch touches the profile sketch at some point
options: Ensure that the path sketch touches the profile sketch at some point
Select the Path Merge option within the sweep feature
Select the Path Intersection option within the sweep feature
Edit the path sketch and reduce any areas of tight curvature

You want to build a new part within an assembly to ensure in-context relations and dimensions. You also want to save out this part file as its own unique file. After navigating to the Assembly ribbon tab, what do you do next?
questions.answer: Under Insert Components, select New Part to create a new in-context part. Right-click the new part and select Save Part (in External File)
correctAnswer: Under Insert Components, select New Part to create a new in-context part. Right-click the new part and select Save Part (in External File)
options: Under Insert Component, select Part to create a new in-context part. Right-click the new part and select isolate
Select Insert Component to create a new in-context part. Right-click te new part and select Save Part (in External File)
Under Insert Components, select New Part to create a new in-context part. Right-click the new part and select Save Selection
Under Insert Components, select New Part to create a new in-context part. Right-click the new part and select Save Part (in External File)

How can you rename a feature?
questions.answer: Select the feature name and press F2, or slow-double-click the feature name
correctAnswer: Select the feature name and press F2, or slow-double-click the feature name
options: Select the feature name and press F2, or slow-double-click the feature name
Select the feature name and press F3 key, or right-click the feature name
Select the feature name and press F7, or quick-double-click the feature name
Select the feature name and press F5 key, or double-click the feature name

questions.question: When using the Fillet tool, what does the Tanget Propagation option do?
questions.answer: It extends the fillet to all faces that are tangent to the selected face
correctAnswer: It extends the fillet to all faces that are tangent to the selected face
options: It creates a fillet that is tanget to the direction of view
It creates a fillet that varies in size, depending on lcoal tangency
It creates a constant-size fillet around all selections
It extends the fillet to all faces that are tangent to the selected face

questions.question: You notice that one of the subassemblies in your main assembly is rigid and does not have mobility it should. How can you resolve this issue?
questions.answer: Select the subassembly and then select **Make Subassembly Flexible** from the context menu
correctAnswer: Select the subassembly and then select **Make Subassembly Flexible** from the context menu
options: Select the subassembly and then select **Make Subassembly Flexible** from the context menu
Select the subassembly and then select **Set Resolved from LightWeight** from the context menu
Select the subassembly and then select **Edit Assembly** from the context menu
Select the subassembly and then select **Make Independent** from the context menu

questions.question: You dimension an arc in a drawing and notice that the dimension is coming in as the radius value. You want to show the diameter value. To do this, first you click the dimension to open the dimension PropertyManager. What do you do next?

In the image below, which are the parents and children of the Vertical Boss Feature?
![solidworks image](images/solidworks_q32.png)
questions.answer: The parent is Base Feature; the children are Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Hole, and Fillet2
correctAnswer: The parent is Base Feature; the children are Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Hole, and Fillet2
options: The parent is Base Feature; the children are Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Hole, and Fillet2
The parent is Vertical Boss; the childre are Base Feature, Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Hole, and Fillet2
The parent is Base Feature; the children are Vertical Boss, Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Holde, and Fillet2
The parents are Vertical Boss and Base Feature; the children are Slot Cutout, Sketch3, CBORE Hole, and Fillet2

questions.question: Why is it useful to suppress a feature?
questions.answer: Suppressing removes a feature from a model, but does not delete it. This is useful if you need that feature back in the future.
correctAnswer: Suppressing removes a feature from a model, but does not delete it. This is useful if you need that feature back in the future.
options: Suppressing changes the color of a feature. This is useful to help easily distinguish between different features.
Suppressing removes a feature from a model, but does not delete it. This is useful if you need that feature back in the future.
Suppressing removes a feature from a model forever. This is useful if you no longer need that feature.
Suppressing makes a feature transparent. This is useful if you ever need to see through a feature when modeling.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the term "parametric modeling"?
questions.answer: The dimensions and relations used to create a feature are captured and stored in the model.
correctAnswer: The dimensions and relations used to create a feature are captured and stored in the model.
options: This type of modeling is often compared to working with modeling clay.
The dimensions and relations used to create a feature are captured and stored in the model.
You can simply push and pull the geometry until you arrive at the shape you require.
Dimensions and relations are not captured or stored within the model.

options: a sketch and an axis of revolution

How can you change the size of a toolbox screw in an assembly?
questions.answer: Right-click the component and select Edit Toolbox Component.
correctAnswer: Right-click the component and select Edit Toolbox Component.
options: Right-click the component and select Edit Toolbox Component.
Toolbox part sizes cannot be changed once added. You have to delete the screw and then readd one of the correct size.
Edit the screw part and add a scale feature using only the required axes.
Open the screw part, then manually adjust the dimensions and save as a copy.

You are designing a robotic arm assembly. You want the first link of the arm to be able to rotate about the base, but only a total of 270 degrees from the start point and no further. How would you achieve this?
How can you reattach a broken reference in a derived split part?
questions.answer: Edit the stock feature at the start of the FeatureManager design tree, then adjust the Defining Stock Part option.
correctAnswer: Edit the stock feature at the start of the FeatureManager design tree, then adjust the Defining Stock Part option.
options: Right-click the filename at the top of the FeatureManager design tree and select Relink Stock Part.
Once derived part references are broken, they cannot be readded. Consider resplitting the part.
Locate the child part using SOLIDWORKS Explorer and select Relink Parent.
Edit the stock feature at the start of the FeatureManager design tree, then adjust the Defining Stock Part option.

questions.question: You have designed a plastic part that you want to split and save in two separate unique parts. You use the Split tool to split the part in half and create the two bodies. What do you do next?
questions.answer: Within the Split tool, click File, double-click the body name, type a name for the new part, and click Save.
correctAnswer: Within the Split tool, click File, double-click the body name, type a name for the new part, and click Save.
options: Navigate to the Solid Bodies folder, right-click the body name, and select Isolate to save to a new file. Repeat for the other body.
Within the Split tool, select Consume Bodies.
Within the Split tool, select Save as New Files.
Within the Split tool, click File, double-click the body name, type a name for the new part, and click Save.

Are planes required to start a 2D sketch?
questions.answer: No, 2D sketches can be created on any planar face of a feature.

options: No, 2D sketches can be created on any planar face of a feature.

No, 2D sketches can be created on any flat or curved surface.

questions.question: You want to share a SOLIDWORKS assembly with another SOLIDWORKS user so that user can edit it. What is the best way to do this?
questions.answer: Use Pack and Go to package and send all assembly files.
correctAnswer: Use Pack and Go to package and send all assembly files.
options: Save the assembly as a sldasm file and send the file to the user.
Save the assembly as a single part (.sldprt file) to include all assembly contents.

Save the assembly as a 3D PDF and select the Enable Editing option.
